title: Feeding Baby: 8 Eating Milestones
author: Gina Shaw

content: There are many milestones that need to be achieved when a baby is ready to start to eat solid foods. Here are some of the big ones.

content_blocks.text: There are many milestones that need to be achieved when a baby is ready to start to eat solid foods. Here are some of the big ones.

sections.heading: Baby Milestone 1: When They Can Start Solids
content: Every baby develops at their own rate. But most pediatricians, and the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP), recommend waiting to introduce solid foods to babies until after they've doubled their birth weight and weigh at least 13 pounds. They're usually at least 4 months old when this happens. That’s also when they start to lose the “ tongue -thrust reflex” or extrusion reflex, which is important for sucking the breast or bottle when they are younger, but interferes with feeding.

Your baby should be able to hold up their head independently and sit up well with support. If they show interest in the foods they see you eating, this may be a good indicator that they're ready for solids..

If you've been breastfeeding your baby, the AAP recommends waiting until they're 6 months old to introduce solids. You should also continue to breastfeed while they start solid foods. You can keep nursing as long as you and your child want to.

content_blocks.text: Every baby develops at their own rate. But most pediatricians, and the American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP), recommend waiting to introduce solid foods to babies until after they've doubled their birth weight and weigh at least 13 pounds. They're usually at least 4 months old when this happens. That’s also when they start to lose the “ tongue -thrust reflex” or extrusion reflex, which is important for sucking the breast or bottle when they are younger, but interferes with feeding.

Your baby should be able to hold up their head independently and sit up well with support. If they show interest in the foods they see you eating, this may be a good indicator that they're ready for solids..

If you've been breastfeeding your baby, the AAP recommends waiting until they're 6 months old to introduce solids. You should also continue to breastfeed while they start solid foods. You can keep nursing as long as you and your child want to.

sections.heading: Baby Milestone 2: When They’re Ready to Move From Puree to Chunks
content: “Chunking up” babies’ food is a process -- obviously, they shouldn’t go straight from rice cereal to raisin bran. But after the first few weeks of adjusting to eating rather than just drinking their food, your baby should be ready to handle a little more texture in solid foods.

Introduce new textures slowly. Good starters are mashed bananas or mashed avocados. You can also use the “staged” store-bought baby foods -- going from the smooth puree of stage 1 to the slightly thicker stage 2 and then the chunkier stage 3 by around 9 months of age. (Babies don’t necessarily have to have a lot of teeth to handle more texture in their foods -- they can often gum soft foods very well!)

To guard against choking, give them small portions and try to get them to eat slowly. Keep an eye on your baby when they eat. Cut foods like hot dogs, string cheese, grapes , and berries into small pieces.

sections.heading: Baby Milestone 3: When They Can Sit in a High Chair
content: When babies are ready to eat solid foods, they can sit upright without support and hold up their head and neck. They're capable of sitting in a high chair! That's a serious milestone, but you'll need to follow these safety rules: Always buckle a baby into their chair for safety, even if they are unable to get out with the tray in place. As they get older and become more active, they may be able to squirm out. It's a good habit to buckle a child as soon as you place them in their chair -- even if you think there's no chance they could fall out or climb out. You may get distracted for a moment, which happens really easily when we are trying to do a million things at once!

sections.heading: Baby Milestone 4: When They Can Manage Finger Foods
content: Babies between ages 7 and 11 months usually tell you they’re ready to eat more grown-up foods by trying to grab them from you. Almost any food that is healthy and nutritious and has a soft texture makes a good finger food, if it’s cut small enough: diced cooked pasta; small pieces of well-cooked vegetables such as carrots, peas , or zucchini; and pea-sized bites of chicken or soft meat. Small, unsweetened round cereals and cereal puffs are also a good choice. Avoid feeding your baby grapes, hot dogs (even cut up), nuts, and hard candy, as they are choking hazards.

content_blocks.text: Babies between ages 7 and 11 months usually tell you they’re ready to eat more grown-up foods by trying to grab them from you. Almost any food that is healthy and nutritious and has a soft texture makes a good finger food, if it’s cut small enough: diced cooked pasta; small pieces of well-cooked vegetables such as carrots, peas , or zucchini; and pea-sized bites of chicken or soft meat. Small, unsweetened round cereals and cereal puffs are also a good choice. Avoid feeding your baby grapes, hot dogs (even cut up), nuts, and hard candy, as they are choking hazards.

content: At first babies “rake” food into their hand, but soon they develop the “pincer grasp” that allows them to pick up small objects between thumb and forefinger. At that point, your baby can become a pro at self-feeding, so encourage finger foods and let your baby explore!

content_blocks.text: At first babies “rake” food into their hand, but soon they develop the “pincer grasp” that allows them to pick up small objects between thumb and forefinger. At that point, your baby can become a pro at self-feeding, so encourage finger foods and let your baby explore!

sections.heading: Baby Milestone 5: When They Start Using Spoons
content: Almost as soon as babies adjust to being fed with a spoon, they'll want to hold and grab the spoon themselves and put it in their mouths. That doesn't mean they're graceful, of course.

Most babies don’t learn to use a spoon effectively until after their first birthday, but let a younger baby who’s interested give it a whirl for practice. Try giving them a soft-tipped spoon to hold while you feed them with another. They can get used to holding the spoon themselves and will also be distracted from grabbing yours.

content: When you think they're ready to actually navigate the spoon into their mouth , try thicker, stickier foods like yogurt , mashed potatoes, or cottage cheese. Another tip: Put some cream cheese on the spoon and then a few pieces of O-shaped cereal on top. The cream cheese won’t fly everywhere, and the baby can get the experience of actually getting the cereal into their mouth.
Expect a mess! Use a plastic or other waterproof bib, and put a mat under the high chair to make cleanup easier.

sections.heading: Baby Milestone 6: When They Can Try Highly Allergenic Foods
content: Experts now recommend offering small amounts of potentially allergenic foods as soon as your baby starts eating solids. These foods include:

Give them these foods one at a time, in small amounts, to see whether they have any signs of an allergic reaction or other issues. Wait three to five days before introducing another new food. If your baby has serious eczema or a reaction to eggs, ask your doctor about the safest way to introduce peanuts into their diet.
Your baby can have some dairy foods, like yogurt and cheese, before they're a year old. But avoid giving them cow's milk or fortified soy drinks before age 1.

If your baby has serious eczema or a reaction to eggs, ask your doctor about the safest way to introduce peanuts into their diet.
Your baby can have some dairy foods, like yogurt and cheese, before they're a year old. But avoid giving them cow's milk or fortified soy drinks before age 1.

sections.heading: Baby Milestone 7: When They Can Drink Water
content: Babies don't need water during their first 6 months of life. They get all the water they need from breast milk or baby formula . Babies under age 6 months should not be given any water at all because it’s easy to fill up their tiny stomachs -- and they should be filling up on the nutrients they receive from the milk to grow. Once they start eating mostly solid foods, around age 9 months, they can start water with meals using a sippy cup.

If your older baby shows an interest in the water that you’re drinking, there’s no harm in letting them have a few sips. Just don’t let it replace the nutritious breast milk or formula they should be getting.

sections.heading: Baby Milestone 8: When They Can Completely Feed Themselves
content: Mastering eating with utensils is a long process. Most babies do not become really skilled at it until they are well past their first birthday. Encourage your child to practice safely, and again, be prepared for a little mess. (How else will you get the “oatmeal in the hair ” pictures that will embarrass them years later?)

sources: Rachel Lewis, MD, assistant professor of clinical pediatrics, Columbia University College of Physicians and Surgeons, New York.
Steven Parker, MD, director, division of behavioral and developmental pediatrics, Boston Medical Center.

Jennifer Shu, MD; co-author, Heading Home with Your Newborn: From Birth to Reality and Food Fights: Winning the Nutritional Challenges of Parenthood Armed with Insight, Humor, and a Bottle of Ketchup .
American Academy of Pediatrics: "Starting Solid Foods."
CDC: "When, What, and How to Introduce Solid Foods."
meta_description: WebMD offers a guide to your baby's 8 feeding milestones -- from starting solid foods to sitting in a high chair, to wielding a spoon.
